profiles:
Experience Systems Analyst Stanford University January 2015  – Present (8 months) Stanford, CA I'm the systems analyst for a multi-institutional software development team involved in designing tools for an open-source web-based software-suite to store, search, and process biomedical images. My core responsibilities include systems administration and systems planning, software engineering, and resource management. Software Developer - Research Stanford University December 2013  – Present (1 year 9 months) Stanford, CA Developed software for analyzing neuroimaging data. Developed a web-based data processing pipeline for automated processing of neuroimaging data. Worked as part of a multi-institutional software development team involved in designing tools for an open-source web-based software-suite to store, search, and process biomedical images. Co-Director and Lead Developer Stanford Talks (talks.stanford.edu) May 2012  – Present (3 years 4 months) Stanford, CA Stanford Talks is dedicated to collecting talks given around the Stanford campus and 
making them accessible to the Stanford community. Our mission is to create a searchable archive of inspiring and educational talks that will enrich the community and foster the educational spirit of Stanford. We currently host over hundreds of talks and continue to collect content. 
 
I am responsible for all aspects of the site and content including: web design and 
development, sever configuration and maintenance. I oversee audio and video capture, post- processing of content, website analytics, account development and billing. Systems Administrator Stanford University November 2011  –  December 2013  (2 years 2 months) Stanford, CA Managed all aspects of the computer system infrastructure for a research lab consisting of 40+ Linux systems including web and compute servers. Sr. Laboratory Manager Stanford University August 2009  –  November 2011  (2 years 4 months) Stanford, CA Laboratory uses neuroimaging methods (fMRI, DTI) and behavior to study the human 
visual system. We study the visual pathways that contribute to reading development as well as making measurements of reorganization following injury and disease. Our work includes extensive software development of tools and simulations. We collaborate extensively with groups in Neuroscience, Electrical Engineering, and Computer Science. Laboratory Manager / Research Assistant Stanford University August 2007  –  August 2009  (2 years 1 month) Stanford, CA Laboratory uses neuroimaging methods (fMRI, DTI) and behavior to study the human 
visual system. We are presently studying the visual pathways that contribute to reading development as well as making measurements of reorganization following injury and disease. Our work includes extensive software development of tools and simulations. We collaborate extensively with groups in Neuroscience, Electrical Engineering, and Computer Science. Staff Research Associate II UC Berkeley School of Public Health September 2006  –  July 2007  (11 months) Berkeley, CA Principal investigator: W. Thomas Boyce, MD. Supervisor: Mark Kishiyama, PhD. 
§ Cross-disciplinary research investigating the effects of socioeconomic inequalities on 
neurological and cognitive development in children utilizing fMRI, EEG, ANS recording 
techniques, and behavioral data. 
§ Recruitment, scheduling, and training of child subjects. EEG, ANS, fMRI, and behavioral 
data collection and analysis. Manage financial accounts, petty cash, and participant reimbursement. Conduct literature reviews. Administration of neuropsychological measures to children, as well as sociodemographic questionnaires to families, both in the lab and in the home. Collaborate and coordinate with researchers in other fields. Research Associate Helen Wills Neuroscience Institute at University of California, Berkeley April 2005  –  July 2007  (2 years 4 months) Berkeley, CA Principal investigator: Robert T. Knight, MD. Supervisor: Mark Kishiyama, PhD. 
Research investigating the effects of emotion and novelty on attention utilizing EEG and 
fMRI technology across multiple populations. 
Subject recruitment, scheduling, and training. EEG and fMRI data collection and analysis. 
Review of scientific literature. Training and supervision of undergraduate research assistants in EEG recording and analysis techniques, as well as fMRI scanning procedures. Summary https://github.com/lrowe 
 
I build web applications for the biologists and biocurators of the ENCODE project, primarily using Python (Pyramid, SQLAlchemy) and Javascript (Backbone, JQuery, React). 
 
I spent many years working on the Open Source CMS Plone, and was responsible for the Diazo XSLT theming system. Much of my Plone consulting involved systems integration, including RDBMS, web services, LDAP and Single Sign On. Summary https://github.com/lrowe
